questions.text: I need a PID provider that offers cost-effective options for registering large numbers of PIDs.
questions.help: For institutions managing many digital objects, cost-efficient PID registration is essential. Some PID providers offer volume-based discounts, non-profit rates, or fee waivers for specific communities.

questions.text: I want a PID that comes with open metadata for re-use.
questions.help: Open metadata enhances discoverability and reuse.

questions.text: I want a PID where persistence is guaranteed with an organisation.
questions.help: Persistence is the core promise of a PID - but itâ€™s not guaranteed by the technology alone. It depends on long-term organizational and financial commitment. Systems like DataCite DOIs, ePIC handles, and URN:NBN are backed by stable institutions/organizations that explicitly commit to maintaining resolvability over time. Handles and ARKs can also support persistence, but this varies with the implementation. Wikidata IDs are maintained by a large community under the Wikimedia Foundation, offering stability through collective stewardship.

questions.text: I want to use my PIDs to point directly to objects, not metadata or landing pages.
questions.help: This is useful when the object itself must be immediately accessible, e.g., raw files or visual artefacts.

questions.text: My organisation does not have the IT capacity to implement Persistent Identifiers in our systems (e.g. collection registration system, website or repository system).
questions.help: Some PID providers offer tools or services for lightweight integration.

questions.text: I want to use a PID provider with transparent information on membership.
questions.help: Clear governance structures promote sustainability and openness.

questions.text: I want to use a PID provider with transparent information on fees.
questions.help: Transparent fees help to plan and assess long-term PID use.

questions.text: I want to have the possibility to delete my PID.
questions.help: Some use cases require deletable PIDs; others require permanent references.

questions.text: I want a centralised system with a central organisation to take care of persistence.
questions.help: Centralisation can simplify responsibility and oversight.

questions.text: I want a decentralised system.
questions.help: Decentralised systems can offer more autonomy and resilience.

questions.text: I want a PID system that comes with a standardised metadata schema.
questions.help: Standards enable interoperability and metadata harvesting.

questions.text: I need a PID system that allows flexible configuration of metadata.
questions.help: Flexibility supports the needs of different domains or workflows.

questions.text: I want to use a PID system with a generic metadata schema to support broad findability.
questions.help: Generic metadata makes it easier to aggregate and index PIDs.

questions.text: I want a PID system that provides interoperability across entity types and domains.
questions.help: Cross-domain compatibility ensures reusability and data exchange.

questions.text: I want to use a PID system that allows entry of discipline- or object-specific metadata.
questions.help: Specific metadata improves precision in discovery.

questions.text: I want a PID that comes with machine-readable metadata.
questions.help: Machine-readable metadata is essential for automation and indexing.

questions.text: I want a PID that provides human-readable metadata on a landing page.
questions.help: Human-readable landing pages support understanding and reuse.

questions.text: I want to use my PID to point directly to the individual entities.
questions.help: This is useful for unpublishable or highly granular internal data.

questions.text: I want to use a PID Provider that offers an API to register PIDs.
questions.help: APIs allow for integration with automated workflows.

questions.text: I want to use a PID Provider that offers manual PID registration.
questions.help: Manual registration can support flexibility and individual workflows.

questions.text: I want to use existing plugins for registering PIDs to ease integration in our own system.
questions.help: Plugins and tools can simplify integration and reduce effort.

questions.text: I want to run my own server to register PIDs for more flexibility and decentralized PID management.
questions.help: Self-hosting provides control but requires technical capacity.
